pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div></div>


<p><strong>In our experience, many payers are dedicating 10 percent or more of administrative spend on care management,</strong><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="053c835e-2d22-4014-a7f6-a7c2b3012087"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="053c835e-2d22-4014-a7f6-a7c2b3012087" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> yet are not seeing return on investment (ROI) from their care-management programs. Many payers have traditionally expressed more confidence in levers such as utilization management, payment integrity, or network to manage medical cost and boost revenue.</p>

<p>The COVID-19 crisis, however, has created a need to reset the vision for payer care management to help payers respond to increased strain on member whole-person health, member concern about visiting common sites of care, and potential risk posed by COVID-19 in skilled nursing facilities. According to a recent <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey</a>, nearly 80 percent of respondents said that they have experienced distress related to COVID-19 and over 50 percent of respondents said that they have felt anxious or depressed over the past week, which may suggest a need for payers to better support whole-person health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="467b7f52-6d76-4db8-80d5-835451c4ab60"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="467b7f52-6d76-4db8-80d5-835451c4ab60" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cordina J, Levin E, and Ramish A, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis">Helping US healthcare stakeholders understand the human side of the COVID-19 crisis</a>: McKinsey Consumer Healthcare Insights, September 18, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, while members are increasingly more comfortable returning to traditional sites of care, some are still not, which may require payers to support care at home for members who feel uncomfortable visiting facilities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="525c88b0-ac6e-4325-bd27-ad484b121065"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="525c88b0-ac6e-4325-bd27-ad484b121065" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cordina J, Seshan N, and Ziani S, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis">Helping US healthcare stakeholders understand the human side of the COVID-19 crisis: McKinsey Consumer Healthcare Insights</a>, June 12, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, concern exists about the risk posed by COVID-19 for skilled nursing facility residents, which may create a need for payers to consider home health capabilities to support post-acute care or long-term care.</p>

<p>Additionally, digital innovations, consumer insights, analytics capabilities, and new vendors have been creating new solutions in the care-management space. These new solutions may help some payers employ innovative strategies for care management.</p>

<p>This paper will discuss next-generation actions that payers may consider to potentially improve the ROI of care management, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members. Although this paper is focused on payers, these actions can be relevant for other risk-bearing entities (for example, accountable care organizations and provider-led health plans).</p>

<h2>Next-generation care management</h2>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-1" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Definition of care management</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>We define care management as any payer-driven efforts to engage with targeted members and their care ecosystems to encourage and enable high-value decisions around their care and improve self-management. We include in our care-management definition complex case management, transition of care, and condition management. We also include multiple engagement modalities, including traditional telephonic or in-person interaction as well as digital and asynchronous coaching and tech-enabled nudges.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8ca5f012-bd09-4646-9e05-dd86e04f06f5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8ca5f012-bd09-4646-9e05-dd86e04f06f5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Many payers often think of care management as nurses connecting with members over the phone to manage a condition, such as diabetes, or to prevent an acute event, such as a readmission. We propose a more expansive definition of care management that involves any payer-driven efforts to engage with targeted members and their care ecosystems to encourage and enable high-value decisions (See Sidebar 1, Definition of care management). We offer four next-generation actions that payers may consider to potentially improve the ROI of their care-management programs, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members: <em>(1) targeting multiple high-potential sources of value, (2) right-sizing care management, (3) engaging members in ways that consumer companies do</em>, and <em>(4) running care management with an operational mindset</em> (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="84509ed1-32dc-4572-97ca-1c656fb9678a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="84509ed1-32dc-4572-97ca-1c656fb9678a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">There are several areas adjacent to care management and the boundaries are blurry. In our definition of care management, we have excluded other medical management levers (for example, utilization management, network, payment integrity, and alternative payment models) and payer member experience levers (for example, enrollment, billing).</span></span></span></a></span> While some payers may be taking these actions and deploying next-generation care management, many others are not in our experience.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c0fefc13-c652-4c6d-9b29-1087fed99e15"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c0fefc13-c652-4c6d-9b29-1087fed99e15" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit1_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Four next-generation actions payers can consider to potentially improve the ROI of care management." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit1_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Based on our experience, through these actions, payers may be able to generate more than two-to-one (2:1+) ROI for care management, meaning that for every $1 invested there may be a $2 return, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2acadbfb-85ef-4de6-b8e1-315eb28dc5ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2acadbfb-85ef-4de6-b8e1-315eb28dc5ee" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> Payers may be able to do this by increasing the percent of medical cost targeted and the percent of members successfully engaged as well as operating more efficiently and reinvesting savings back into care management (Exhibit 2).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit2_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="An example equation shows how next-generation actions can potentially improve care management ROI." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit2_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>1. Target multiple high-potential sources of value</h3>

<p>Payers can target sources of value that can be achieved while a member is still enrolled with their plan and broaden the sources of value that they target. They can also target the relevant sources of value for each member archetype.</p>

<p><strong>Broaden sources of value</strong></p>

<p>Exhibit 3, below, is a McKinsey framework that outlines comprehensive sources of value for payers across medical cost and revenue opportunities.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="This framework indicates potential payer sources of value." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Payers work to obtain these sources of value with many levers, and the most successful payers potentially see two-to-five percent savings from care management.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa6325db-1266-4f4f-b24d-1eff63dc8bc9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa6325db-1266-4f4f-b24d-1eff63dc8bc9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> In our experience, many payers capture less value than this range based on two major factors. First, many care-management programs do not target sources of value that can be achieved while a member is still enrolled with a plan. For example, many payers have wellness programs, which may result in value only by preventing a medical event many years after the member has left the plan. Other programs, especially complex case-management and transitions-of-care programs, may result in more immediate value. Second, payer care-management programs often have a narrow focus on preventing medical events. They fail to address other sources of value, such as helping members select the most clinically appropriate site of care or the highest-quality and most-efficient provider.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>

<p>Payer care-management programs can target several potential medical cost and revenue sources of value:</p>

<ul>
<li>Medical cost sources of value:
<ul>
<li>Most care-management programs focus on preventable medical events. For example, care management can engage a member with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to promote good self-management via medication adherence, thereby potentially preventing medical events resulting in costly emergency department (ED) visits.</li>
<li>In our experience, site of care, unit price, and appropriate diagnosis (Dx), treatment, and management have been under-targeted by care management to date.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9ee0e9cd-2ca7-4539-a8bf-cb6bef95ee52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9ee0e9cd-2ca7-4539-a8bf-cb6bef95ee52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> For instance, a care manager can engage a patient who may be recommended for discharge to a skilled nursing facility following a hospital stay and instead help support the patients discharge to the home.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Revenue sources of value:
<ul>
<li>Clinically appropriate and accurate coding may be improved via care management. For example, a care manager may assess that a member has potentially progressed to the next stage of chronic kidney disease. The care manager can coordinate a visit for the member to a nephrologist to diagnose and appropriately code this condition.</li>
<li>Care management can help close care gaps and improve Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS) performance. In Medicare, improved performance on Stars, which measures how well Medicare plans perform on quality of care and member service, can potentially lead to a more patient-oriented approach and to additional direct premium dollars through Stars quality bonus payments. The plan can then allocate those dollars back into benefits, ultimately satisfying and attracting more members.</li>
<li>Buy-ups and member attraction and retention may be increased via care management. First, payers can offer care-management programs as buy-up opportunities, or increased coverage, for employer plan sponsors to potentially improve employee experience. Second, an attractive portfolio of care-management programs may promote member attraction and retention, though payers have struggled to quantify this impact.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Target the right source of value for each member archetype</strong></p>

<p>Exhibit 4, below, is a McKinsey framework that outlines example relevant sources of value for representative member archetypes (for example, members with specialty chronic conditions, members with primary care treatable conditions) enrolled in Medicare Advantage.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Each example member archetypes in Medicare Advantage may have different potential sources of value." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Certain sources of value may be more or less significant for different member archetypes and different lines of business (for example, Medicare Advantage, Commercial, Medicaid); even if certain sources are less significant, a payer might choose to pursue them, as these benefits can still be of value to the members. Payers often target the same source of value for all members identified for care management rather than target the specific needs of different member archetypes. For example, care management that may reduce preventable medical events can be helpful for members in Medicare Advantage who have had recent acute episodes. However, optimizing site of care, appropriate diagnosis, treatment, and management, and clinically appropriate and accurate coding, may be more relevant for members in Medicare Advantage with specialty chronic conditions. Payers may seek to evaluate their care-management portfolios against the relevant sources of value for different member archetypes. They may consider changing interventions that are not currently targeting sources of value for member archetypes and filling any gaps.</p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Segmenting members based on psychographic factors could help payers concentrate outreach on membersmore receptive to care management.</p></blockquote></div>

<h3>2. Potential to right-size care management to member need at a point in time</h3>

<p>The intensity of care management may be considered with the clinically inappropriate spend and needs of a targeted population. Payers can also consider ways to engage members when they are possibly more receptive to care management.</p>

<p><strong>Consider ways to match the intensity of care management to the needs of the targeted population</strong></p>

<p>Ideally, the intensity of care management (for example, the size and expertise of the care team, frequency of interaction, engagement modality, and duration of engagement) should be tailored to address clinically inappropriate spend and meet the needs of the targeted population. However, this focus is not what we see today. Instead, we see a focus on total spend rather than potentially clinically inappropriate spend. Moreover, the intensity of care-management interventions is generally not tailored to different levels of member needs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="03f8c7a8-561e-441d-b549-69af80edb723"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="03f8c7a8-561e-441d-b549-69af80edb723" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Having multiple care-management intensity options can help both higher- and lower-needs members receive adequate care. The highest-need members with higher clinically inappropriate medical spend (for example, members with multiple comorbidities and substantial clinically inappropriate inpatient/ED spend) may receive more intensive complex case management (for example, frequent interaction with a multidisciplinary care team, in-person and digital engagement, and six months or longer of engagement). Lower-needs members with lower clinically inappropriate medical spend (for example, a member with well-managed diabetes) may be candidates for lighter-touch digitally enabled condition management (for example, escalation to the members care team as needed and digitally enabled reminders and health coaching), while maintaining positive ROI.</p>

<p>Importantly, this tailored approach can be deployed to address members needs while keeping potential or expected ROI in mind (Exhibit 5). For example, for each population, a payer can identify the total estimated clinically inappropriate spend and set a care-management budget to potentially deliver 2:1+ ROI.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit5_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Payers can set a segment-specific budget to potentially deliver a 2:1 ROI for care management based on total estimated clinically inappropriate spend." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit5_v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="The future of healthcare: Value creation through next-generation business models" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20value%20creation/standard-future-healthcare-697564199.png?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The future of healthcare: Value creation through next-generation business models</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-future-of-healthcare-value-creation-through-next-generation-business-models" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Engage members when they are most receptive to care management</strong></p>

<p>Few payers engage members when they are most receptive to care management and when maximum cost-savings potential exists. For example, in Exhibit 5, members in the highest risk group may not be impactable at any time because they are asymptomatic or well managed and therefore unmotivated to engage in care management. To realize the full value of care management, payers may consider engaging members around health inflection points, such as a surgery or discharge from a hospital.</p>

<h3>3. Engage members as a consumer company does</h3>

<p>Payers may better engage members by improving data sets to identify more potential members, enhance member contact information and leverage multiple channels to reach members, consider psychographic segmentation approaches to engage more members, and consider an engagement first approach to more successfully support member behavior change.</p>

<p>Healthcare has been relatively slow to pick up consumer engagement trends, such as micro-targeting, personalization, and sticky engagement tactics, that are used in the technology and consumer sectors. As a result, and as we discussed in our article <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/supercharging-the-roi-of-your-care-management-programs">Supercharging the ROI of your care management programs</a>, payer care management can leave 90 percent or more of potential value on the table because payers are not able to engage the vast majority of members they identify for care management (Exhibit 6).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72d6ae9d-5b95-4f63-aeb1-ec3c82f356ea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72d6ae9d-5b95-4f63-aeb1-ec3c82f356ea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bestsennyy O, Scharen J, and Shah A, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/supercharging-the-roi-of-your-care-management-programs">Supercharging the ROI of your care management programs</a>, August 6, 2019, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> That said, boosting care-management performance is possible now more than ever with digital innovations, consumer insights, analytics capabilities, and vendors.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Over 90 percent of value may be left on the table by payers." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20untapped%20potential%20of%20payer%20care%20management/svg_untappedpayercaremgmt_exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p><strong>Improve data sets used for member identification</strong></p>

<p>Payers often rely on historical claims data, which has a lag and does not fully represent member needs, for member identification. In one client example, a readmissions program relied on claims data and reached out to members several weeks after they had gone home from the hospital. At that point, the payer was likely no longer able to prevent a readmission by ensuring the member understood the discharge instructions, had the appropriate support at home, and had follow-up appointments scheduled. In our experience, some payers are starting to improve member identification for care management by using rich data sets, such as admissions, discharges, and transfers (ADT) feeds and utilization management prior authorization.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a0ca786e-64a6-4636-b9a7-717237eedda7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a0ca786e-64a6-4636-b9a7-717237eedda7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p><strong>Enhance member contact information and leverage multiple channels to reach members</strong></p>

<p>Payers often have outdated contact information and rely on traditional methods of outreach, such as nurses trying to call members at home. In one example, we found a payer had 60 percent of member contact information missing or incorrect. One care manager at the payer recounted that she tried to call a member every day at the same time on his home phone number because that is the time his number would come up on her call list. Once she got his cell phone number and determined a good time to reach him, she started calling him at that time. To reach members successfully, payers may consider enhancing member contact information and leverage multiple channels (text, email, phone, in-person) to reach members based on their preferences.</p>

<p><strong>Consider psychographic segmentation to initiate engagement</strong></p>

<p>In our experience, payers typically see that around 50 percent of members who are contacted for care management opted not to enroll in the care-management program or left before completion of the program.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f4196ff2-7876-4f2c-9231-595b5b74318e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f4196ff2-7876-4f2c-9231-595b5b74318e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> Segmenting members based on psychographic factors could help payers concentrate outreach on members who may be more receptive to care management and tailor communications to be more effective. Payers may have some of these capabilities in their marketing and sales organizations, which often segment customers by engagement level and purchasing behavior.</p>

<p><strong>Take an engagement first approach toward behavior change</strong></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Innovations creating new solutions in the care-management space</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Digital innovations:</strong> Advancements in technology have opened up a new avenue for reaching patients. Eighty-one percent of Americans have smartphones today (compared with 35 percent in 2011).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0edf3daa-1a9b-4e81-aa33-a96e3d3bdb52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0edf3daa-1a9b-4e81-aa33-a96e3d3bdb52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mobile fact sheet, Pew Research Center, June 12, 2019, pewresearch.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Payers can reach these individuals via various channels (text, apps, and video) and in a scalable yet personalized fashion. Patients are also increasingly open to virtual care, especially given COVID-19. In one of our recent consumer surveys, 37 percent of respondents said they are very likely to use telehealth in the future once the COVID-19 pandemic ends (when stay-at-home restrictions, if any, are no longer required in their area).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="12a2fef6-29ef-4367-9c3e-f006db80e173"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="12a2fef6-29ef-4367-9c3e-f006db80e173" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cordina J, Stein G, and Levin E, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis">Helping US healthcare stakeholders understand the human side of the COVID-19 crisis: McKinsey Consumer Healthcare Insights</a>, July 22, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p><strong>Consumer insights:</strong> Healthcare has largely lagged other industries in terms of understanding consumers and maximizing engagement. In <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-future-of-personalization-and-how-to-get-ready-for-it">The future of personalizationand how to get ready for it</a>, we highlight examples of how retailers are using apps to generate personalized offers and product recommendations to consumers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d772b0d4-08bb-4c7b-83da-95d71ee6ab20"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d772b0d4-08bb-4c7b-83da-95d71ee6ab20" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Boudet J, Gregg B, Rathje K, Stein E, and Vollhardt K, <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-future-of-personalization-and-how-to-get-ready-for-it">The future of personalizationand how to get ready for it</a>, June 18, 2019, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Payers may take advantage of these previously paved roads to know what consumers prefer and how to engage them.</p>

<p><strong>Analytics capabilities:</strong> Payers now have access to new data that did not previously exist, such as consumer data and social determinants of health data. This data may help payers better predict which members can benefit from interventions, which interventions they may most benefit from, when those interventions can take place, and how the members can be engaged.</p>

<p><strong>Vendors:</strong> Payers no longer need to build all capabilities internally. They can make build versus buy versus partner decisions for each component as they create a care-management ecosystem, which can be of potential value to regional payers who may not have the scale to build a best in class capability internally.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Changing behaviors first and foremost comes with keeping members engaged beyond the first conversation. Once the member is engaged, many payers shift immediately to behavior-change interventions (for example, quitting smoking, modifying diet) but do not incorporate incentives for the member to continue engaging. Payers may learn from other consumer-facing industries that take an engagement first approach by making sure the offering is both initially attractive and sticky to keep members coming back, at which point the behavior-change intervention can be delivered. Based on member interviews, some members are not clear what their care-management programs can do for them. Care managers can work to better understand unique member pain points (for example, understanding the condition, scheduling an appointment, finding transportation, coordinating across doctors), address them to earn the members engagement, and then provide coaching (Sidebar 2).</p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Intensity of care managementshould be tailored to address clinically inappropriate spend and meet the needs of the targeted population.</p></blockquote></div>

<h3>4. Run care management with an operational mindset</h3>

<p>Payers may run care management with an operational mindset by setting clear operational metrics (for example, setting staffing ratios, case length expectations, and case graduation criteria; ensuring top of license practices; and digitizing and automating processes).</p>

<p>Some payers, despite significant investment, are not certain about the ROI of their care management efforts. In our experience, a big range of ROI exists, even when the programs are delivering impact.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9978402d-129a-4481-9e47-8d2ae6b8cf89"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9978402d-129a-4481-9e47-8d2ae6b8cf89" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> Most payers could consider a more disciplined approach to care-management investment and operations.</p>

<p><strong>Consider setting clear operational metrics</strong></p>

<p>In our experience, payers are often running care management without clear targets around operational metrics, such as clinically appropriate nurse staffing ratios, case lengths or expected reach, and engagement and graduation rates. Even with these standards in place, we often observe substantial variability in performance of those metrics among staff.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="02b1267b-f895-4a9c-a995-e4a4cb4e6709"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="02b1267b-f895-4a9c-a995-e4a4cb4e6709" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on aggregate McKinsey client experience.</span></span></span></a></span> Payers can consider implementing appropriate performance-management approaches (for example, dashboards, performance dialogues) to help achieve operational standards.</p>

<p><strong>Ensure top of license practices</strong></p>

<p>Payers often use clinical staff to perform all steps in the care-management process, including administrative tasks and member engagement duties that do not require a clinical license. As a result, a big portion of a clinical staff members time may be spent on non-member-facing tasks.</p>

<p>Payers can consider non-clinical staff for tasks that do not require clinical licensure, such as initial outreach to members, health screens, and task coordination.</p>

<p><strong>Digitize and automate processes</strong></p>

<p>Payers often conduct many care-model processes manually (such as calling members, prioritizing cases, assigning cases to case managers, or filling out assessments with known data). They can make smart investments into digital technology and automation on appropriate tasks to minimize time spent by staff on manual tasks. For example, a payer can invest in robo-dialers to call members, automated algorithms to prioritize cases and assign them to case managers, and capabilities to automatically populate assessments with known data.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Go-forward workplan for payers to realize the potential of care management</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>There are eight tactical next steps that payers can consider. The near-term action items may help drive targeted, high-priority investments over the longer term.</p>

<p><strong>Near-term actions: Evaluate operational efficiency and consider program reprioritization</strong></p>

<ul>
<li><em>Rapidly conduct ROI analysis</em> of current programs. Consider reprioritizing low-value programs to create capacity to reinvest into high-value programs.</li>
<li><em>Identify pain points</em> in the care-manager workflow that may waste time. Consider solutions for pain points to create efficiency savings.</li>
<li><em>Establish clinically appropriate operational efficiency</em> and effectiveness targets (for example, caseloads, graduation rates). Introduce dashboards to rigorously monitor performance.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Longer-term actions: Consider program redesign options that enhance value and effectiveness</strong></p>

<ul>
<li><em>Assess current care-management</em> portfolio and interventions against potential sources of value. Rebalance the program portfolio toward programs that target major potential sources of value, and within programs, rebalance efforts toward interventions that do the same (for example, within complex chronic disease management, consider shifting focus toward preventable medical events).</li>
<li><em>Segment the population</em> by clinically inappropriate spend, understand the budget for each segment to generate a 2:1+ ROI, and ensure appropriate investment in segments (or make a conscious choice to over-invest in some segments to promote some non-medical cost value creation).</li>
<li><em>Boost abilities</em> to identify and target members in a timely fashion by incorporating rich data sets (for example, ADT feeds, utilization management prior authorization) and real-time outreach channels (for example, text).</li>
<li><em>Create a customer experience task force</em> (or use an existing forum) to bring together marketing and care-management teams. Discuss what customer segmentation and information on member channel preferences can be shared and incorporated into care-management design.</li>
<li><em>Take a market-backed view</em> on what plan sponsor employers value. Engage sales team (and possibly brokers) to ensure portfolio meets plan sponsor needs.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>By creating a strategic plan that considers targeting multiple high-potential sources of value, right-sizing care management to member need at a point in time, engaging members the way a consumer company would, and running care management with an operational mindset, payers may improve the ROI on their care-management programs, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members (Sidebar 3). Realizing the potential of care management will be especially important as payers face financial headwinds and members face increased needs during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. The time for payers to act is now.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Oleg Bestsennyy</strong> is a partner in McKinseys New York office. <strong>Michelle Chmielewski</strong> is an associate partner in the Chicago office. <strong>Anne Koffel</strong> is an associate partner in the Boston office. <a href="/our-people/amit-shah"><strong>Amit Shah</strong></a> is a partner in the New York office.</p>

COVID-19."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-01-25T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn our experience, many payers are dedicating 10 percent or more of administrative spend on care management,\u003c/strong\u003e[[footnote 1]] yet are not seeing return on investment (ROI) from their care-management programs. Many payers have traditionally expressed more confidence in levers such as utilization management, payment integrity, or network to manage medical cost and boost revenue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 crisis, however, has created a need to reset the vision for payer care management to help payers respond to increased strain on member whole-person health, member concern about visiting common sites of care, and potential risk posed by COVID-19 in skilled nursing facilities. According to a recent \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eMcKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey\u003c/a\u003e, nearly 80 percent of respondents said that they have experienced distress related to COVID-19 and over 50 percent of respondents said that they have felt anxious or depressed over the past week, which may suggest a need for payers to better support whole-person health.[[footnote 2]] Additionally, while members are increasingly more comfortable returning to traditional sites of care, some are still not, which may require payers to support care at home for members who feel uncomfortable visiting facilities.[[footnote 3]] Furthermore, concern exists about the risk posed by COVID-19 for skilled nursing facility residents, which may create a need for payers to consider home health capabilities to support post-acute care or long-term care.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAdditionally, digital innovations, consumer insights, analytics capabilities, and new vendors have been creating new solutions in the care-management space. These new solutions may help some payers employ innovative strategies for care management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThis paper will discuss next-generation actions that payers may consider to potentially improve the ROI of care management, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members. Although this paper is focused on payers, these actions can be relevant for other risk-bearing entities (for example, accountable care organizations and provider-led health plans).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eNext-generation care management\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eMany payers often think of care management as nurses connecting with members over the phone to manage a condition, such as diabetes, or to prevent an acute event, such as a readmission. We propose a more expansive definition of care management that involves any payer-driven efforts to engage with targeted members and their care ecosystems to encourage and enable high-value decisions (See Sidebar 1, \u0026ldquo;Definition of care management\u0026rdquo;). We offer four next-generation actions that payers may consider to potentially improve the ROI of their care-management programs, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members: \u003cem\u003e(1) targeting multiple high-potential sources of value, (2) right-sizing care management, (3) engaging members in ways that consumer companies do\u003c/em\u003e, and \u003cem\u003e(4) running care management with an operational mindset\u003c/em\u003e (Exhibit 1).[[footnote 4]] While some payers may be taking these actions and deploying next-generation care management, many others are not in our experience.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eBased on our experience, through these actions, payers may be able to generate more than two-to-one (2:1+) ROI for care management, meaning that for every $1 invested there may be a $2 return, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members.[[footnote 6]] Payers may be able to do this by increasing the percent of medical cost targeted and the percent of members successfully engaged as well as operating more efficiently and reinvesting savings back into care management (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Target multiple high-potential sources of value\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers can target sources of value that can be achieved while a member is still enrolled with their plan and broaden the sources of value that they target. They can also target the relevant sources of value for each member archetype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBroaden sources of value\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eExhibit 3, below, is a McKinsey framework that outlines comprehensive sources of value for payers across medical cost and revenue opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers work to obtain these sources of value with many levers, and the most successful payers potentially see two-to-five percent savings from care management.[[footnote 7]] In our experience, many payers capture less value than this range based on two major factors. First, many care-management programs do not target sources of value that can be achieved while a member is still enrolled with a plan. For example, many payers have wellness programs, which may result in value only by preventing a medical event many years after the member has left the plan. Other programs, especially complex case-management and transitions-of-care programs, may result in more immediate value. Second, payer care-management programs often have a narrow focus on preventing medical events. They fail to address other sources of value, such as helping members select the most clinically appropriate site of care or the highest-quality and most-efficient provider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayer care-management programs can target several potential medical cost and revenue sources of value:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMedical cost sources of value:\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMost care-management programs focus on preventable medical events. For example, care management can engage a member with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to promote good self-management via medication adherence, thereby potentially preventing medical events resulting in costly emergency department (ED) visits.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn our experience, site of care, unit price, and appropriate diagnosis (Dx), treatment, and management have been under-targeted by care management to date.[[footnote 8]] For instance, a care manager can engage a patient who may be recommended for discharge to a skilled nursing facility following a hospital stay and instead help support the patient\u0026rsquo;s discharge to the home.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRevenue sources of value:\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClinically appropriate and accurate coding may be improved via care management. For example, a care manager may assess that a member has potentially progressed to the next stage of chronic kidney disease. The care manager can coordinate a visit for the member to a nephrologist to diagnose and appropriately code this condition.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCare management can help close care gaps and improve Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS) performance. In Medicare, improved performance on Stars, which measures how well Medicare plans perform on quality of care and member service, can potentially lead to a more patient-oriented approach and to additional direct premium dollars through Stars quality bonus payments. The plan can then allocate those dollars back into benefits, ultimately satisfying and attracting more members.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBuy-ups and member attraction and retention may be increased via care management. First, payers can offer care-management programs as \u0026ldquo;buy-up\u0026rdquo; opportunities, or increased coverage, for employer plan sponsors to potentially improve employee experience. Second, an attractive portfolio of care-management programs may promote member attraction and retention, though payers have struggled to quantify this impact.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTarget the right source of value for each member archetype\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eExhibit 4, below, is a McKinsey framework that outlines example relevant sources of value for representative member archetypes (for example, members with specialty chronic conditions, members with primary care treatable conditions) enrolled in Medicare Advantage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eCertain sources of value may be more or less significant for different member archetypes and different lines of business (for example, Medicare Advantage, Commercial, Medicaid); even if certain sources are less significant, a payer might choose to pursue them, as these benefits can still be of value to the members. Payers often target the same source of value for all members identified for care management rather than target the specific needs of different member archetypes. For example, care management that may reduce preventable medical events can be helpful for members in Medicare Advantage who have had recent acute episodes. However, optimizing site of care, appropriate diagnosis, treatment, and management, and clinically appropriate and accurate coding, may be more relevant for members in Medicare Advantage with specialty chronic conditions. Payers may seek to evaluate their care-management portfolios against the relevant sources of value for different member archetypes. They may consider changing interventions that are not currently targeting sources of value for member archetypes and filling any gaps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Potential to right-size care management to member need at a point in time\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe intensity of care management may be considered with the clinically inappropriate spend and needs of a targeted population. Payers can also consider ways to engage members when they are possibly more receptive to care management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsider ways to match the intensity of care management to the needs of the targeted population\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIdeally, the intensity of care management (for example, the size and expertise of the care team, frequency of interaction, engagement modality, and duration of engagement) should be tailored to address clinically inappropriate spend and meet the needs of the targeted population. However, this focus is not what we see today. Instead, we see a focus on total spend rather than potentially clinically inappropriate spend. Moreover, the intensity of care-management interventions is generally not tailored to different levels of member needs.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHaving multiple care-management intensity options can help both higher- and lower-needs members receive adequate care. The highest-need members with higher clinically inappropriate medical spend (for example, members with multiple comorbidities and substantial clinically inappropriate inpatient/ED spend) may receive more intensive complex case management (for example, frequent interaction with a multidisciplinary care team, in-person and digital engagement, and six months or longer of engagement). Lower-needs members with lower clinically inappropriate medical spend (for example, a member with well-managed diabetes) may be candidates for lighter-touch digitally enabled condition management (for example, escalation to the member\u0026rsquo;s care team as needed and digitally enabled reminders and health coaching), while maintaining positive ROI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eImportantly, this tailored approach can be deployed to address members\u0026rsquo; needs while keeping potential or expected ROI in mind (Exhibit 5). For example, for each population, a payer can identify the total estimated clinically inappropriate spend and set a care-management budget to potentially deliver 2:1+ ROI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 5]]\n\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEngage members when they are most receptive to care management\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFew payers engage members when they are most receptive to care management and when maximum cost-savings potential exists. For example, in Exhibit 5, members in the \u0026ldquo;highest risk\u0026rdquo; group may not be impactable at any time because they are asymptomatic or well managed and therefore unmotivated to engage in care management. To realize the full value of care management, payers may consider engaging members around \u0026ldquo;health inflection points,\u0026rdquo; such as a surgery or discharge from a hospital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Engage members as a consumer company does\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers may better engage members by improving data sets to identify more potential members, enhance member contact information and leverage multiple channels to reach members, consider psychographic segmentation approaches to engage more members, and consider an \u0026ldquo;engagement first\u0026rdquo; approach to more successfully support member behavior change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHealthcare has been relatively slow to pick up consumer engagement trends, such as micro-targeting, personalization, and sticky engagement tactics, that are used in the technology and consumer sectors. As a result, and as we discussed in our article \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/supercharging-the-roi-of-your-care-management-programs\"\u003eSupercharging the ROI of your care management programs\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; payer care management can leave 90 percent or more of potential value \u0026ldquo;on the table\u0026rdquo; because payers are not able to engage the vast majority of members they identify for care management (Exhibit 6).[[footnote 10]] That said, boosting care-management performance is possible now more than ever with digital innovations, consumer insights, analytics capabilities, and vendors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 6]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImprove data sets used for member identification\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers often rely on historical claims data, which has a lag and does not fully represent member needs, for member identification. In one client example, a readmissions program relied on claims data and reached out to members several weeks after they had gone home from the hospital. At that point, the payer was likely no longer able to prevent a readmission by ensuring the member understood the discharge instructions, had the appropriate support at home, and had follow-up appointments scheduled. In our experience, some payers are starting to improve member identification for care management by using rich data sets, such as admissions, discharges, and transfers (ADT) feeds and utilization management prior authorization.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnhance member contact information and leverage multiple channels to reach members\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers often have outdated contact information and rely on traditional methods of outreach, such as nurses trying to call members at home. In one example, we found a payer had 60 percent of member contact information missing or incorrect. One care manager at the payer recounted that she tried to call a member every day at the same time on his home phone number because that is the time his number would come up on her call list. Once she got his cell phone number and determined a good time to reach him, she started calling him at that time. To reach members successfully, payers may consider enhancing member contact information and leverage multiple channels (text, email, phone, in-person) to reach members based on their preferences.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsider psychographic segmentation to initiate engagement\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn our experience, payers typically see that around 50 percent of members who are contacted for care management opted not to enroll in the care-management program or left before completion of the program.[[footnote 12]] Segmenting members based on psychographic factors could help payers concentrate outreach on members who may be more receptive to care management and tailor communications to be more effective. Payers may have some of these capabilities in their marketing and sales organizations, which often segment customers by engagement level and purchasing behavior.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTake an \u0026ldquo;engagement first\u0026rdquo; approach toward behavior change\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eChanging behaviors first and foremost comes with keeping members engaged beyond the first conversation. Once the member is engaged, many payers shift immediately to behavior-change interventions (for example, quitting smoking, modifying diet) but do not incorporate incentives for the member to continue engaging. Payers may learn from other consumer-facing industries that take an \u0026ldquo;engagement first\u0026rdquo; approach by making sure the offering is both initially attractive and sticky to keep members coming back, at which point the behavior-change intervention can be delivered. Based on member interviews, some members are not clear what their care-management programs can do for them. Care managers can work to better understand unique member pain points (for example, understanding the condition, scheduling an appointment, finding transportation, coordinating across doctors), address them to earn the member\u0026rsquo;s engagement, and then provide coaching (Sidebar 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Run care management with an operational mindset\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers may run care management with an operational mindset by setting clear operational metrics (for example, setting staffing ratios, case length expectations, and case graduation criteria; ensuring \u0026ldquo;top of license\u0026rdquo; practices; and digitizing and automating processes).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSome payers, despite significant investment, are not certain about the ROI of their care management efforts. In our experience, a big range of ROI exists, even when the programs are delivering impact.[[footnote 13]] Most payers could consider a more disciplined approach to care-management investment and operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsider setting clear operational metrics\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn our experience, payers are often running care management without clear targets around operational metrics, such as clinically appropriate nurse staffing ratios, case lengths or expected reach, and engagement and graduation rates. Even with these standards in place, we often observe substantial variability in performance of those metrics among staff.[[footnote 14]] Payers can consider implementing appropriate performance-management approaches (for example, dashboards, performance dialogues) to help achieve operational standards.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnsure \u0026ldquo;top of license\u0026rdquo; practices\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers often use clinical staff to perform all steps in the care-management process, including administrative tasks and member engagement duties that do not require a clinical license. As a result, a big portion of a clinical staff member\u0026rsquo;s time may be spent on non-member-facing tasks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers can consider non-clinical staff for tasks that do not require clinical licensure, such as initial outreach to members, health screens, and task coordination.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar disclaim]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDigitize and automate processes\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePayers often conduct many care-model processes manually (such as calling members, prioritizing cases, assigning cases to case managers, or filling out assessments with known data). They can make smart investments into digital technology and automation on appropriate tasks to minimize time spent by staff on manual tasks. For example, a payer can invest in robo-dialers to call members, automated algorithms to prioritize cases and assign them to case managers, and capabilities to automatically populate assessments with known data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 3]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eBy creating a strategic plan that considers targeting multiple high-potential sources of value, right-sizing care management to member need at a point in time, engaging members the way a consumer company would, and running care management with an operational mindset, payers may improve the ROI on their care-management programs, while also ensuring a better, healthier experience for members (Sidebar 3). Realizing the potential of care management will be especially important as payers face financial headwinds and members face increased needs during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. The time for payers to act is now.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-01-25T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBased on aggregate McKinsey client experience.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCordina J, Levin E, and Ramish A, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eHelping US healthcare stakeholders understand the human side of the COVID-19 crisis\u003c/a\u003e: McKinsey Consumer Healthcare Insights,\u0026rdquo;
